content:
As pointed out in Niako's comment below, there is a lot of duplication in the statement. I've revised the puzzle as follows:

Goal
* Removed all repetitions.

* Changed [[N]] to [[n_people]] for consistency.

Input
* Added the word "space-separated" in the last description.

Output
* Formatted the variables.

* Removed all repetitions.

* Added "<<A number of lines>>".

Constraints
* Removed descriptions of variables.

Stub generator
* Changed "string" to 2 ints of i and j.

Tags
* Added the tag "Connected components".
Added "write answer" to stub generator, and formatted the constant 5 in the constraints.

Hum, this puzzle is not really in a great shape...
Why are there 2 distinct input/output/constraints sections?
The stub does not properly parse the links.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice. Requires some decent understanding of lists (especially contain and join). Interesting edge cases.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good

The stub script should be changed to use 2 ints for the related elements instead of a string.
Also, add a write command for output. e.g.

loop nlinks read i:int j:int
write join(3,1)
write join(1,2)

OUTPUT
"cluster size" and "cluster count" for each cluster, separated by a space; in descending order of size.

Good puzzle, but I think you can push the limit to constrain the performance.
I solved it with a Map and some Sets, and I'm confident you can handle thousands that way.

Ready to approve but it would be great if you could respond to Schwase post first.

Good puzzle, heres a suggestion for your written portions:

Statement:
Given a population size and a network of connections between its members, determine the breakdown of cluster sizes of the population.

Imagine that each member of a population is one person. Now consider that one member of the population becomes "infected" by a virus. Provided a set of connections (i.e. "member A is linked to member B"), the subset of members of the population infected by the virus can be simulated (we will assume that transmission is guaranteed to occur between linked members). This subset is effectively like an "outbreak" of a virus.

Your job is to assess these subsets, or <<clusters>> and provide the breakdown of the distribution of cluster sizes in the given population.

NOTE: All links are two-way, there are no one-way links.

Given a population size [[N]], with members indexed from {{0}} to {{N-1}}, calculate the size of every outbreak/cluster within the population.

Input:

<<Line 1:>> A number, [[N]], of members of the population
<<Line 2:>> A number, [[L]], of links within the population
<<Next L lines:>> Two space-separated integers representing the indexes of two linked members of the population

Output:

<<Line 1:>> Two space-separated integers representing the size and frequency of the largest sized cluster.
<<Line 2:>> Two space-separated integers representing the size and frequency of the 2-nd largest sized cluster
... and so on:
<<Last Line:>> Two space-separated integers representing the size and frequency of the smallest sized cluster

Constraints:

{{5}} <= [[N]] <= {{500}}
{{800}} > L
Every member of the population belongs to a cluster

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

I just resolved all test cases and they seem to be fine.
In the Goal text, just fix "clusters of person" and "Let see"

Thanks for the contribution, really enjoyed it

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Originale et dans l'air du temps

I think this could be a nice puzzle to learn about BFS. To me, the statement and protocol need a bit of work:
- unless you plan on making this a series, there is no point, in my opinion, to mention a virus or a probability of transmission yet. Or at least, make it a side story at the end of the statement.
- improve the description of the output.
The constraint "Number of people 5 < n_people <= 500" is not right : in 1st entry, n_people == 5.

Nice puzzle!

I highly disagree about the comment saying "the theme is inappropriate for the time being." and anything close to it. This is a math/logic problem... A good one and nothing more. There is no opinion of any kind, so no reason to "moderate". Additionnaly, I see nothing bad in a coding inspiration coming from the reality. To the opposite, in fact.

I enjoyed the challenge of this problem which took me ~3hours of head scratching ending in 82 lines of JavaScript.

But I have suggestions about the puzzle instructions:

I deducted expected output from the test case attempts in the IDE. "size of the biggest cluster number of clusters of this size" just mystified me...

I would replace the word "cluster(s)" with "group(s)" in the description, globally.

I would keep the first sentence of the description: "In this puzzle, we look at the GROUPS of person who can be infected by a virus in a given population."

And I would discard the rest in favor of:

Your challenge is to identify all the groups of persons having a relationship.
Each separate group having absolutely no relation with any other group.
And produce a report about all existing group size.

Inputs: (keep as is)
Outputs: n lines, one for each groups sizes. Each lines containing two integers, "group size" and "group count" for this group size, separated by a space.
Constraints: (keep as is)

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: IAmNoob is a bot.

edit: And so am I. :/

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: i sad down :)

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Yes, yes, yes, finally a decent medium puzzle.
keep doing :)

"A cluster is a sub-set within which any element is linked to the others directly or not. In other words, each person outside the cluster is not "connected" to anyone inside the cluster."

The wording here is very unclear. That first sentence doesn't make much sense. What you are really talking about is a connected subset of maximal size.

I solved the puzzle and agree with it being a Medium, however I'd say you can probably push the limits a bit higher. A standard BFS implementation should be able to cope with larger numbers of people and links.

Also, maybe better not to mention Covid-19? It's kind of irrelevant, and people are sick of hearing about it everywhere they look.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The puzzle is challenging and clear enough. Fits well in the medium category.

Ok. I solved it in Python, in a somehow simple way. I pass all the tests.

I will validate your puzzle, but first you must get your text checked by an English speaker.

You can't use "people" when talking about an individual. It is a collective noun ("Les gens"). You must replace with "person". (each person outside the cluster...)

This sentence is not correct : "A cluster is a sub-set within any element is linked to the others directly or not" 

(I would suggest "within which", but check with a native speaker)

"people can be immune and then, does not transmit the virus" => "don't" (people is plural)
"People has at least 1 connexion" => "People have..." or "Everybody has..." 

In the Input section, you have "Ligne 1" and "Ligne 2" in French. Then, in the Output section, it is "Line1" and "Line n", in English

And so on...

And I agree with selenae : the commentary on the limits of the model is a bit of an overkill.
I think it it not relevant to describe the reality. We know that a simple coding puzzle is different from reality.
You are right. A little bug in the solution has been modified and the test case and validator are now different.
But it could be interesting to know where the modeling goes far from reality. It is just for fun and the culture.
Thanks for your review I made a revision.
Thanks

I agree to remove the mention to COVID 19 it is not very popular...
Thank for your comment.
Thank you
And by the way, the theme is inappropriate for the time being.

First of all thanks for your constructive comment.
I revised the puzzle regarding your comments. But some things must remain such as naming : it is not "group" but "cluster". A cluster is a set with properties and a group is another thing (for instance we could have group of clusters...).

Thanks again.

Ok thanks, I changed the condition.

Thank you for your comment, if ok for you don't forget to validate.

Kind regards
french spotted. ;)

I like the puzzle a lot but hopefully you can reword it. Please reply directly to me when you have made changes (please do not think you HAVE to take my recommendations), so that I can reevaluate the puzzle and hopefully approve it! Good luck!

Thanks for your contribution, I put it in the statement.

Kind regards,
Cool !

Thanks a lot for your great contribution.
I put it in the statement with some few modifications or add-on.

Kind regards,

If you have another algorithm that can be better to tackle higher dimension for several type of connexion, feel free to share it.
Thanks again.
The algorithm is just BFS, which has a run time of O(n_people + n_links), so it should be fine for much higher values of n_links.

You are almost there with that thing about person/people :) 
I validate the puzzle but please fix :

 ..we look at the clusters of person who can be infected.. = > ...the clusters of people... (or the clusters of personS)
...People has at least 1 connexion... => ...people have...

(Every time you can translate it by "gens", it is "people". You can say "un groupe de gens", but you can't say "chaque gen" ! ; You can say "les gens ont" but you can't say "les gens a")

And please add a "write" line in the stub generator. It is always nice to people who are learnig a new langage.

Also, in the constraints, n_links should be >= 1

And here is a nice "≤" sign ! ;)
I foolishly thought you would fix those issues...

Now I am passing all tests and validators. 
I think there are still tests and validators that are the same in some of the cases.
Also in the stub generator width should be replaced with npeople or something similar. 
Finally the text might need to be ironed out a bit.
Regards.

Thank for your deep review.
I changed all validator to be sure it is not the same as test.
I also changed the format of output to simplify.
I increase the number of population after optimisation.
Finally I have made a review of the test.
Hope it fits !
Thanks.
